Thanassis Psaltis

Nuclear astrophysics and science communication

We use big machines and computers to study how stars that blow up in space create the stuff we are made of.
Current Research

Learn more about our ongoing projects in experimental and theoretical nuclear astrophysics. Find recent publications, talks, and current projects.

For Prospective Students

Interested in nuclear physics or astrophysics research? There may be opportunities to work on experimental data analysis, nuclear reaction modeling, and computational astrophysics. Find out below how to get started!

Science Outreach

Public talks, articles, and resources on nuclear astrophysics and the broader story of how stars create the elements.

Outreach Blog


The Cassiopeia A supernova remnant, captured by NASA's James Webb Space Telescope in near-infrared light. This is the aftermath of a massive star‚Äôs explosion about 340 years ago, its expanding cloud of gas and dust still glowing with the energy of that cosmic blast. Image credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, Danny Milisavljevic (Purdue University), Ilse De Looze (UGent), Tea Temim (Princeton University)

The carbon in your DNA, the oxygen you are breathing, and the indium in the computer screen you are using right now‚Äîall were forged during the lives and explosive deaths of stars. Our research seeks to answer a fundamental question: ‚ÄúWhat is the origin of the chemical elements?‚Äù The rarest elements, such as gold, silver, and platinum, are created in the universe‚Äôs most violent explosions, including supernovae and neutron star mergers. We aim to determine precisely what comes out of these extreme environments, using a combination of experimental, theoretical, and observational approaches.

We collaborate with researchers worldwide, proposing and conducting experiments at leading nuclear physics facilities, including TRIUMF (Canada), RIKEN (Japan), GSI (Germany), FRIB, Argonne National Lab, and TUNL (United States). These experiments allow us to recreate the nuclear processes that happen in the most exotic stellar explosions in the universe.

Science should be accessible to everyone. Our group engages with the public through lectures, hands-on workshops for students, and collaborations with science festivals both in Canada and internationally. Through these initiatives, we aim to inspire curiosity about the universe and bring the story of the stars closer to all audiences.
